ground_truth: Loomis makes it to the front porch and tentatively steps up to the door. He glances back to his friends in the street. The boy turns to open the door, then Loomis' POV moves back to Lonnie at the front door. He's scared out of his mind. Lonnie spins around and stares in horror at the talking hedge. Moving like the wind, Lonnie barrels off the porch and races back to his friends. The boys hurtle off down the street in utter terror. Loomis quietly stands up behind the hedge. He watches them race away, smiling to himself. Suddenly, two hands enter frame and grab Loomis' shoulders. Loomis jumps and spins around. Standing there is Brackett. Brackett turns and walks back to the street. A car pulls up in front of the house and parks. Its lights flick off. The sounds of laughter come from inside. Bob Simms, a good-looking 17-year-old, pops open a can of beer. Next to him, Lynda guzzles hers. The lights are all out. Bob opens the door and together they fall out onto the ground. The can of beer falls over onto the front seat. They embrace. Bob grabs Lynda and she starts giggling. Bob picks Lynda up and carries her up to the front door. Lynda squirms in Bob's arms. As he sets her down, her foot accidentally hits the front door and it swings open. Lynda and Bob both stop. Bob and Lynda enter the house. The living room is empty. The lights are off. Lynda and Bob enter the house and begin turning on the lights. Bob walks over to Lynda. They embrace. They kiss. Bob pulls Lynda over to the couch and turns out the light. A shadow comes over them. They continue kissing, unaware of the shape of a man on the stairway watching. The house is totally black inside. Then an orange light floats around the room. As it gets closer, we see that Laurie is carrying a Jack-O-Lantern, with a candle illuminating from the center of the pumpkin. Behind Laurie are Lyndsey and Tommy making scary noises. The procession continues through the house. The procession continues to the front window. Laurie places the Jack-O-Lantern on the window sill. She looks down the street toward the Wallaces. Laurie sees Bob's car parked in front of the house. Laurie sits down on the couch and sighs. Lindsey and Tommy cuddle up with her, one on either side. Laurie gets up to answer it. Lynda hangs up the phone and grins. Bob grins. Lynda grabs Bob's hand and stands up. Lynda pulls Bob up from the couch and they walk quickly up the stairs. She walks to the window and glances out.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Loomis reaches it to the front veranda and cautiously steps up to the entrance. He peeks back to his companions in the road. The lad rotates to open the entrance, then Loomis' POV shifts back to Lonnie at the front entrance. He's terrified out of his wits. Lonnie twirls around and gapes in dread at the speaking shrub. Moving like the breeze, Lonnie dashes off the veranda and sprints back to his companions. The lads dash off down the road in absolute panic. Loomis silently stands up behind the shrub. He observes them speed away, grinning to himself. Suddenly, two hands enter frame and seize Loomis' shoulders. Loomis leaps and spins around. Standing there is Brackett. Brackett rotates and strides back to the road. A vehicle pulls up in front of the dwelling and stops. Its lights flick off. The sounds of chuckling emanate from inside. Bob Simms, a handsome 17-year-old, pops open a tin of ale. Next to him, Lynda gulps hers. The lights are all out. Bob opens the entrance and together they tumble out onto the ground. The tin of ale tips over onto the front seat. They hug. Bob seizes Lynda and she begins giggling. Bob lifts Lynda up and carries her up to the front entrance. Lynda wriggles in Bob's arms. As he sets her down, her foot unintentionally hits the front entrance and it swings open. Lynda and Bob both halt. Bob and Lynda enter the dwelling. The sitting room is vacant. The lights are off. Lynda and Bob enter the dwelling and begin switching on the lights. Bob strides over to Lynda. They hug. They kiss. Bob pulls Lynda over to the sofa and switches out the light. A silhouette comes over them. They persist kissing, oblivious of the shape of a man on the staircase observing. The dwelling is entirely dark inside. Then an amber light floats around the room. As it gets closer, we discern that Laurie is carrying a Jack-O-Lantern, with a candle illuminating from the center of the pumpkin. Behind Laurie are Lyndsey and Tommy making frightening sounds. The procession continues through the dwelling. The procession continues to the front window. Laurie places the Jack-O-Lantern on the window sill. She looks down the road toward the Wallaces. Laurie sees Bob's vehicle parked in front of the dwelling. Laurie sits down on the sofa and exhales. Lindsey and Tommy snuggle up with her, one on either side. Laurie gets up to answer it. Lynda hangs up the phone and smirks. Bob smirks. Lynda seizes Bob's hand and stands up. Lynda pulls Bob up from the sofa and they walk swiftly up the staircase. She walks to the window and glances out.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Loomis steps onto the porch and approaches the door, glancing back at his friends. As he turns the doorknob, the scene cuts to Lonnie at the door, terrified. He spins and stares in horror at the talking hedge before bolting back to his friends, who flee in panic. Loomis rises quietly behind the hedge, smiling as he watches them run. Suddenly, hands grab his shoulders—he jumps and turns to see Brackett, who then walks off. A car parks outside the house and laughter comes from within. Bob Simms, a handsome 17-year-old, cracks open a beer as Lynda gulps hers. With the lights off, Bob opens the door and they tumble out. They embrace, Bob lifts Lynda, and she giggles. Her foot bumps the door, which swings open. They pause, then go inside. The living room is dark and empty. They turn on lights, kiss, and Bob pulls Lynda to the couch, switching off the light. A shadow looms over them—a man watches from the stairs. The house goes black. An orange light appears—Laurie carries a Jack-O-Lantern lit from within, followed by Lyndsey and Tommy making spooky sounds. They move through the house to the front window. Laurie sets the Jack-O-Lantern on the sill and sees Bob’s car parked at the Wallaces’. She sits with the kids on the couch, one on each side. Laurie gets up to answer the phone. Lynda hangs up smiling, grabs Bob’s hand, and they head upstairs. She pauses to glance out the window.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Loomis reaches the porch, glancing at friends in the street. He opens the door, Loomis' POV shifts to Lonnie, terrified by the talking hedge. Lonnie bolts back to his friends, all fleeing in terror. Loomis smiles from behind the hedge. Suddenly, hands grab Loomis' shoulders; it's Brackett, who walks to the street. A car parks, laughter inside. Bob Simms, 17, opens a beer. Lynda drinks hers. They fall out, embracing. Bob carries Lynda to the door, her foot swings it open. They enter, turning on lights. Bob and Lynda kiss on the couch, unaware of a man on the stairway. Laurie, with a Jack-O-Lantern, leads Lyndsey and Tommy through the house. Laurie places the Jack-O-Lantern on the window sill, sees Bob's car. Laurie sits with Lindsey and Tommy. Laurie answers the phone. Lynda grins, grabs Bob's hand, and they head upstairs. She looks out the window.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: Loomis cautiously makes his way to the front porch, taking careful, tentative steps as he approaches the door. He pauses for a moment, casting a glance back toward his friends who are waiting in the street. The boy then turns his attention to the door, preparing to open it. At this moment, Loomis' point of view shifts back to Lonnie, who is standing at the front door. Lonnie is visibly terrified, scared out of his mind. In a sudden, panicked motion, Lonnie spins around, his eyes wide with horror as he stares at the hedge that seems to be talking. Moving with the speed of the wind, Lonnie bolts off the porch, racing back to the safety of his friends. The group of boys, gripped by utter terror, hurtles down the street. Meanwhile, Loomis quietly rises from his position behind the hedge, watching them flee with a smile of satisfaction on his face. Suddenly, two hands appear in the frame, firmly grabbing Loomis by the shoulders. Startled, Loomis jumps and spins around to find Brackett standing there. Without a word, Brackett turns and begins to walk back toward the street. At that moment, a car pulls up in front of the house and comes to a stop, its headlights flicking off. From inside the vehicle, the sounds of laughter can be heard. Bob Simms, a handsome 17-year-old, pops open a can of beer. Seated next to him, Lynda eagerly guzzles her own drink. The house is shrouded in darkness, with all the lights turned off. Bob opens the car door, and together they tumble out onto the ground, the can of beer tipping over onto the front seat. They embrace warmly, and Bob playfully grabs Lynda, causing her to giggle. With a playful grin, Bob lifts Lynda into his arms and carries her up to the front door. Lynda squirms playfully in Bob's embrace, and as he sets her down, her foot accidentally nudges the front door, causing it to swing open. Both Lynda and Bob pause momentarily. They then proceed to enter the house, finding the living room empty and the lights still off. As they step inside, Lynda and Bob begin turning on the lights, illuminating the space. Bob approaches Lynda, and they embrace once more, sharing a tender kiss. Bob gently pulls Lynda over to the couch, and with a flick, he turns out the light. A shadow looms over them, but they remain engrossed in their kiss, unaware of the silhouette of a man standing on the stairway, silently watching. The interior of the house is now completely enveloped in darkness. Suddenly, an orange light begins to float around the room. As it draws nearer, it becomes clear that Laurie is carrying a Jack-O-Lantern, its candle casting a warm glow from the center of the carved pumpkin. Following closely behind Laurie are Lyndsey and Tommy, who are making playful, scary noises. The small procession continues to move through the house, eventually reaching the front window. Laurie carefully places the Jack-O-Lantern on the window sill, its light flickering gently. She gazes down the street toward the Wallaces' house and notices Bob's car parked in front. With a sigh, Laurie sits down on the couch, and Lindsey and Tommy snuggle up beside her, one on each side. Laurie rises to answer it. Lynda hangs up the phone with a grin, and Bob mirrors her expression. Lynda takes hold of Bob's hand and stands up, pulling him up from the couch. Together, they walk quickly up the stairs. Lynda walks to the window and glances out, taking in the scene outside.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: Loomis advances cautiously toward the front porch, making his way with careful, tentative steps as he edges closer to the door. He pauses briefly, casting a backward glance toward his friends who are anxiously waiting out in the street. The boy then shifts his focus back to the door, steeling himself to open it. At this crucial moment, Loomis' perspective swings back to Lonnie, who is standing nervously at the front door. Lonnie is visibly terrified, utterly scared out of his mind. In a sudden, panicked motion, Lonnie whirls around, his eyes wide with horror as he stares at the hedge, which appears to be talking. Like a swift gust of wind, Lonnie dashes off the porch, frantically racing back to the refuge of his friends. The group of boys, consumed by sheer terror, hurtles down the street together. Meanwhile, Loomis quietly rises from his concealed position behind the hedge, watching them flee with a satisfied smile on his face. Suddenly, two hands emerge into the frame, firmly grasping Loomis by the shoulders. Startled, Loomis jumps and spins around to find Brackett standing there. Without uttering a word, Brackett turns and begins his walk back toward the street. At that precise moment, a car pulls up in front of the house, coming to a halt with its headlights flicking off. From inside the vehicle, the joyous sounds of laughter can be heard. Bob Simms, a handsome 17-year-old, pops open a can of beer with a satisfying hiss. Seated right next to him, Lynda eagerly guzzles her own drink. The house stands shrouded in darkness, with not a single light turned on. Bob opens the car door, and together they tumble out onto the ground, the can of beer tipping over onto the front seat. They embrace warmly, and Bob playfully grabs Lynda, causing her to giggle with delight. With a playful grin spreading across his face, Bob lifts Lynda into his arms and carries her up to the front door. Lynda squirms playfully in Bob's embrace, and as he sets her down, her foot accidentally nudges the front door, causing it to swing open. Both Lynda and Bob pause momentarily, exchanging glances. They then proceed to enter the house, finding the living room empty and still cloaked in darkness. As they step inside, Lynda and Bob begin to turn on the lights, illuminating the space with a warm glow. Bob approaches Lynda, and they embrace once more, sharing a tender and affectionate kiss. Bob gently pulls Lynda over to the couch, and with a flick, he turns out the light once more. A mysterious shadow looms over them, but they remain engrossed in their kiss, unaware of the silhouette of a man standing on the stairway, silently watching them. The interior of the house is now completely enveloped in darkness. Suddenly, an orange light begins to float around the room. As it draws nearer, it becomes evident that Laurie is carrying a Jack-O-Lantern, its flickering candle casting a warm glow from the center of the intricately carved pumpkin. Following closely behind Laurie are Lyndsey and Tommy, who are making playful, scary noises. The small procession continues to move through the house, eventually reaching the front window. Laurie carefully places the Jack-O-Lantern on the window sill, its soft light flickering gently. She gazes down the street toward the Wallaces' house and notices Bob's car parked in front. With a gentle sigh, Laurie sits down on the couch, and Lindsey and Tommy snuggle up beside her, one on each side, nestled closely. Laurie rises to answer it. Lynda hangs up the phone with a broad grin, and Bob mirrors her expression with equal enthusiasm. Lynda takes hold of Bob's hand and stands up, pulling him up from the couch. Together, they walk quickly up the stairs, eager to explore the unknown. Lynda walks to the window and glances out, taking in the entire scene unfolding outside.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Loomis cautiously approaches the front porch, each step deliberate as he ascends to the door. He pauses momentarily, casting a glance back at his friends who linger in the street, seeking reassurance or perhaps a final moment of courage. The boy turns his attention to the door, his hand reaching out to open it, but Loomis' perspective shifts back to Lonnie, who stands at the front door, visibly terrified. Lonnie, overwhelmed by fear, spins around abruptly, his eyes wide with horror as he stares at the hedge that seems to be speaking. In a sudden burst of panic, Lonnie propels himself off the porch with the speed of the wind, racing back to his friends with urgency. The group of boys, gripped by terror, collectively hurtle down the street, their feet pounding the pavement as they flee. Loomis, having quietly risen from his position behind the hedge, watches their retreat with a satisfied smile playing on his lips. Without warning, two hands enter the frame, firmly grasping Loomis' shoulders, causing him to jump and spin around in surprise. Standing before him is Brackett, who, without a word, turns and begins to walk back toward the street. As Brackett departs, a car pulls up in front of the house, its engine purring to a stop as the headlights flick off, leaving the scene in darkness. From within the car, the sound of laughter spills out, and Bob Simms, a handsome 17-year-old, pops open a can of beer, the crisp sound echoing in the quiet. Beside him, Lynda eagerly guzzles her own drink, the two of them enveloped in the carefree spirit of youth. With the car's lights extinguished, Bob opens the door, and together they tumble out onto the ground, the can of beer tipping over onto the front seat in their playful clumsiness. They embrace, laughter mingling with the night air, as Bob wraps his arms around Lynda, who responds with a fit of giggles. In a playful gesture, Bob lifts Lynda into his arms, carrying her up to the front door, her body squirming with delight. As he sets her down, her foot inadvertently strikes the door, causing it to swing open unexpectedly. Both Lynda and Bob pause, momentarily taken aback by the open door, before stepping inside the house. The living room greets them with emptiness, the absence of light casting shadows across the space. Undeterred, Lynda and Bob begin to illuminate the room, turning on lights as they move through the house. Bob approaches Lynda, drawing her into an embrace, their lips meeting in a kiss that speaks of youthful passion. He gently pulls her over to the couch, where they settle, and with a flick of his hand, he turns out the light, plunging the room back into darkness. Unbeknownst to them, a shadow looms over their intimate moment, the silhouette of a man standing on the stairway, silently observing. The house is enveloped in total darkness, save for an orange light that begins to float around the room. As it draws nearer, it becomes clear that Laurie is carrying a Jack-O-Lantern, its candle casting a warm glow from within the carved pumpkin. Behind Laurie, Lyndsey and Tommy follow, their voices raised in playful, scary noises that echo through the house. The procession moves steadily through the rooms, eventually reaching the front window. Laurie carefully places the Jack-O-Lantern on the window sill, its light casting a flickering glow against the glass. She gazes out the window, her eyes tracing the street until they land on Bob's car parked in front of the house. With a sigh, Laurie sinks onto the couch, Lindsey and Tommy nestling against her, one on each side, seeking comfort in her presence. Laurie rises to answer the phone, her movements deliberate. Meanwhile, Lynda hangs up the phone, a grin spreading across her face as she shares a knowing look with Bob. Bob returns her grin, and Lynda, with a playful tug, pulls Bob up from the couch. Together, they walk quickly up the stairs, their footsteps a soft thud on the carpet. Lynda pauses at the window, her gaze drifting outside as she takes in the scene beyond.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Loomis reaches the front porch, hesitantly approaches the door, and glances back at his friends. As Lonnie nervously turns to open the door, he is startled by a voice from the hedge, causing him to flee in terror with his friends. Loomis, amused, watches them run away before being surprised by Brackett, who then returns to the street. A car arrives, and Bob Simms and Lynda, both laughing, exit with beers in hand. They embrace, and Bob carries Lynda to the front door, accidentally swinging it open with her foot. They enter the dark, empty house, turning on lights as they go. After embracing and kissing, they move to the couch, unaware of a shadowy figure watching from the stairs. Meanwhile, Laurie, carrying a Jack-O-Lantern, leads Lyndsey and Tommy through the house, placing the pumpkin on the window sill. She notices Bob's car outside, sits on the couch with the children, and answers the phone. Lynda hangs up, grins at Bob, and they head upstairs together. Laurie glances out the window.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Loomis makes it to the front porch, a classic American Craftsman-style feature of many suburban homes, and tentatively steps up to the door. He glances back to his friends lingering in the street, a familiar place of youthful gatherings. The boy turns to open the door, then Loomis' point of view shifts back to Lonnie at the front door, a symbol of adolescent bravery and fear all at once. He's scared out of his mind, his fear palpable under the pale moonlight of Halloween. Lonnie spins around and stares in horror at the talking hedge, an eerie setting that looms with the supernatural aura of the neighborhood's spooky legends. Moving like the wind, Lonnie barrels off the porch and races back to his friends. The boys hurtle off down the street in utter terror, their sneakers pounding on the pavement echoing like a haunting melody. Loomis quietly stands up behind the hedge, once planted by a local gardener aiming to add privacy and mystique. He watches them race away, smiling to himself, a knowing grin of someone who understands the seasonal adventures of trick-or-treating night. Suddenly, two hands enter the frame and grab Loomis' shoulders. Loomis jumps and spins around. Standing there is Brackett, the seasoned town sheriff known for his vigilant patrols. Brackett turns and walks back to the street. A car pulls up in front of the house and parks. Its lights flick off, leaving the street bathed in shadows. The sounds of laughter come from inside. Bob Simms, a good-looking 17-year-old with a reputation for being the life of the party, pops open a can of beer in the dim light of the car interior. Next to him, Lynda guzzles hers, the fizzy drink spilling slightly as it catches the moonlight. The lights are all out in the neighborhood as Halloween night deepens. Bob opens the door and together they fall out onto the ground, their laughter echoing into the night air. The can of beer falls over onto the front seat, leaving a stain that tells tales of teenage rebellion. They embrace, young love in its reckless delight. Bob grabs Lynda and she starts giggling, the carefree sound carrying into the silent night. Bob picks Lynda up and carries her up to the front door. Lynda squirms in Bob's arms, her playful spirit unrestrained. As he sets her down, her foot accidentally hits the front door and it swings open, creaking ominously. Lynda and Bob both stop, caught in a moment of quiet surprise. Bob and Lynda enter the house, stepping into the hushed darkness of the unknown. The living room is empty, an eerily inviting space. The lights are off, concealing the mysteries of the house. Lynda and Bob enter the house and begin turning on the lights, illuminating the space with warm, flickering light. Bob walks over to Lynda, the room now glowing with the ambiance of their presence. They embrace, drawing each other close in the soft light. They kiss, lost in their private world. Bob pulls Lynda over to the couch and turns out the light, casting them back into shadow. A shadow comes over them, a silent figure that is the specter of their youthful indiscretions. They continue kissing, unaware of the shape of a man on the stairway watching with a predatory gaze. The house is totally black inside, a blank canvas of suspense and intrigue. Then an orange light floats around the room, a beacon in the dark. As it gets closer, we see that Laurie is carrying a Jack-O-Lantern, with a candle illuminating from the center of the pumpkin, a traditional symbol of Halloween's haunting charm. Behind Laurie are Lyndsey and Tommy making scary noises, their innocent playfulness adding a spooky yet lighthearted tone to the evening. The procession continues through the house, an unbroken line of wonder and mystery. The procession continues to the front window, where the night is mirrored in its glass. Laurie places the Jack-O-Lantern on the window sill, a guardian of light against the encroaching shadows. She looks down the street toward the Wallaces, the neighbors known for their extravagant Halloween decorations. Laurie sees Bob's car parked in front of the house, a telltale sign of teenage mischief. Laurie sits down on the couch and sighs, the weight of the night's events settling on her shoulders. Lindsey and Tommy cuddle up with her, one on either side, their presence a comforting reminder of human connection. Laurie gets up to answer it, her footsteps light on the creaky floorboards. Lynda hangs up the phone and grins, a conspiratorial smile shared in the dim light. Bob grins, sharing in her mischievous delight. Lynda grabs Bob's hand and stands up, pulling him into her orbit. Lynda pulls Bob up from the couch and they walk quickly up the stairs, their footfalls echoing in the stillness. She walks to the window and glances out, the night stretching before her like an enigma.

Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Lynda and Bob both stop. Bob and Lynda enter the house. The living room is empty. The lights are off. Lynda and Bob enter the house and begin turning on the lights. Bob walks over to Lynda. They embrace. They kiss. Bob pulls Lynda over to the couch and turns out the light. A shadow comes over them. They continue kissing unaware of the shape of a man on the stairway watching. The house is totally black inside. Then an orange light floats around the room. As it gets closer we see that Laurie is carrying a JackOLantern with a candle illuminating from the center of the pumpkin. Behind Laurie are Lyndsey and Tommy making scary noises. The procession continues through the house. The procession continues to the front window. Laurie places the JackOLantern on the window sill. She looks down the street toward the Wallaces. Laurie sees Bob's car parked in front of the house. Laurie sits down on the couch and sighs. Lindsey and Tommy cuddle up with her one on either side. Laurie gets up to answer it. Lynda hangs up the phone and grins. Bob grins. Lynda grabs Bob's hand and stands up. Lynda pulls Bob up from the couch and they walk quickly up the stairs. She walks to the window and glances out.

test_cases.name: Addition (~80%)
test_cases.description: Loomis makes it to the front porch and tentatively steps up to the door. He glances back to his friends in the street. The boy turns to open the door. then Loomis' POV moves back to Lonnie at the front door. He is scared out of his mind. Lonnie spins around and stares in horror at the talking hedge. Moving like the wind Lonnie barrels off the porch and races back to his friends. The boys hurtle off down the street in utter terror. Loomis quietly stands up behind the hedge. He watches them race away smiling to himself. Suddenly two hands enter frame and grab Loomis' shoulders. Loomis jumps and spins around. Standing there is Brackett. Brackett turns and walks back to the street. A car pulls up in front of the house and parks. Its lights flick off. The sounds of laughter come from inside. Bob Simms a goodlooking 17yearold pops open a can of beer. Next to him. Lynda guzzles hers. The lights are all out. Bob opens the door and together they fall out onto the ground. The can of beer falls over onto the front seat. They embrace. Bob grabs Lynda and she starts giggling. Bob picks Lynda up and carries her up to the front door. Lynda squirms in Bob's arms. As he sets her down her foot accidentally hits the front door and it swings open. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Zeke sneaks onto the back deck and cautiously hops up to the fence. She peers over to her cousins in the yard. The girl pivots to unlock the fence, then Zeke's perspective shifts back to Charlie at the gate. She's petrified beyond belief. Charlie twirls around and gapes in astonishment at the whispering tree. Darting like lightning, Charlie zooms off the deck and dashes back to her cousins. The girls zoom away up the lane in complete panic. Zeke silently crouches down beside the tree. She observes them darting away, chuckling to herself. Abruptly, four paws emerge into view and tap Zeke's knees. Zeke leaps and turns around. Sitting there is Murphy. Murphy pivots and strides back to the avenue. A truck rolls in beside the fence and halts. Its beams switch off. The sounds of singing emanate from within. Oscar Blake, an attractive 15-year-old, cracks open a bottle of soda. Beside him, Maria chugs hers. The beams are all dimmed. Oscar unlatches the gate and together they tumble out onto the turf. The bottle of soda tips over onto the back seat. They hug. Oscar clasps Maria and she begins chuckling. Oscar hoists Maria up and carries her up to the porch. Maria squirms in Oscar's grasp. As he places her down, her elbow inadvertently nudges the porch railing and it swings ajar. Maria and Oscar both halt. Oscar and Maria venture into the yard. The den is vacant. The beams are dimmed. Maria and Oscar venture into the yard and commence turning on the beams. Oscar strides over to Maria. They hug. They peck. Oscar tugs Maria over to the swing and dims the beam. A silhouette hovers above them. They persist in pecking, oblivious to the figure of a dog on the stairwell observing. The garden is entirely shadowy within. Then a purple glow drifts across the patio. As it drifts nearer, we perceive that Kelly is carrying a Lantern with a bulb glowing from the core of the vessel. Trailing Kelly are Jamie and Teddy making spooky whispers. The parade advances through the garden. The parade advances to the patio door. Kelly places the Lantern on the doorstep. She scrutinizes the avenue toward the Millers. Kelly spots Oscar’s truck stationed beside the fence. Kelly lowers herself onto the swing and exhales. Jamie and Teddy snuggle up with her, one on either flank. Kelly rises to answer it. Maria drops the phone and beams. Oscar beams. Maria clutches Oscar's paw and rises. Maria tugs Oscar up from the swing and they sprint hurriedly up the corridor. She strides to the patio and peers out.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Loomis approaches the front porch, glancing at his friends. As Lonnie fearfully retreats from a talking hedge, Loomis smiles. Suddenly grabbed by Brackett, Loomis is startled. A car parks outside, and Bob Simms, a 17-year-old, shares beers and laughs with Lynda. They exit the car, embrace, and Bob carries her to the house. When Lynda accidentally nudges the door open, they enter the dark, empty living room, turn on lights, and share a kiss on the couch. Unbeknownst to them, a man watches from the stairs. Laurie, carrying a Jack-O-Lantern with Lyndsey and Tommy, places it by the window, noticing Bob's car outside. As Laurie relaxes with the children, Lynda and Bob ascend the stairs after a phone call.
